-1002657093374.html: The crisis of Ukrainian Orthodoxy through the eyes of Europe: an outside view At a webinar organized by the Sofia Brotherhood and the Renovabis Foundation, Belarusian human rights defender Natallia Vasilevich spoke about how the European ecumenical community perceives Ukrainian Orthodoxy. Until 2022, the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (UOC) was seen as the representative of Ukraine, while the Orthodox Church of Ukraine (OCU) remained on the periphery. After the start of the full-scale war, the statements and behavior of certain representatives of the UOC played a key role in destroying Kremlin propaganda on the international stage. However, the situation has changed since 2023: the OCU has intensified its international activity, while the UOC has withdrawn from the dialogue, but at the same time expects support. This duality creates tension and distrust. European churches avoid criticizing Ukraine, but are wary of the implementation of Law 8371, fearing systemic violations of religious freedom. The main challenge is the lack of dialogue between the UOC and the OCU. Instead of communication, there is public confrontation, mutual accusations, and growing toxicity. This destroys the image of both sides and forms a negative perception of Ukrainian Orthodoxy as a whole. According to Vasilevich, the way out is through joint educational, cultural, and theological initiatives that unite, rather than divide. Self-criticism and the ability to show solidarity with a "competitor" are signs of maturity, which are sorely lacking today. #ukraine #uoc #ocu Source channel: test_source

-1002674864764.html:
Another sentence was handed down in Izhevsk for transfers to "undesirable organizations" from Ukraine

On May 5, it became known about a new sentence in Udmurtia: a resident of Izhevsk was found guilty of "financing undesirable organizations" - the Ukrainian spiritual center "Revival" and the charitable foundation of the same name, associated with the preacher Vladimir Muntyan.

According to the court, in 2022-2023, the woman transferred 17,000 rubles to their accounts. For this, she received 240 hours of community service under Part 2 of Article 284.1 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation. Earlier, the activities of Muntyan's organizations in Russia were recognized as undesirable.

As the Sova Center notes, it is likely that this refers to 25-year-old Dinara Akhmetova, who was sentenced by the Oktyabrsky District Court of Izhevsk on April 30.

üì∑: United Press Service of the Courts of Udmurtia #russia #protestants Source channel: test_source

Z-bloggers were offended: the crosses disappeared from the coat of arms of Russia in Chechnya

The head of Chechnya, Ramzan Kadyrov, published a video of another award ceremony for his son Adam. This time, it was a commemorative medal for the 25th anniversary of the OMON "Akhmat Grozny". Pro-war bloggers noticed that the ceremony was held against the background of the Russian coat of arms, from which one of the elements - the crosses - had been removed (this is clearly visible on the orb).

Who will be held responsible for the fact that the state symbol was distorted at an official event? - wrote the blogger Kirill Fedorov in Telegram.

The "war correspondent" Yuri Kotenok noted that "Orthodox crosses have already been erased a hundred times on covers, posters and signs", but this has not happened with the state coat of arms before.

One of the largest pro-war Telegram channels "Two Majors" writes that "it is precisely such stories that sow discord in interethnic relations".

The authorities of Chechnya did not comment on the situation.

#Russia #Muslims #Orthodox Source channel: test_source

The crisis of Ukrainian Orthodoxy through the eyes of Europe: an outside view

At a webinar organized by the Sofia Brotherhood and the Renovabis Foundation, Belarusian human rights defender Natallia Vasilevich spoke about how the European ecumenical community perceives Ukrainian Orthodoxy. Until 2022, the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (UOC) was seen as the representative of Ukraine, while the Orthodox Church of Ukraine (OCU) remained on the periphery. After the start of the full-scale war, the statements and behavior of certain representatives of the UOC played a key role in destroying Kremlin propaganda on the international stage.

However, the situation has changed since 2023: the OCU has intensified its international activity, while the UOC has withdrawn from the dialogue, but at the same time expects support. This duality creates tension and distrust. European churches avoid criticizing Ukraine, but are wary of the implementation of Law 8371, fearing systemic violations of religious freedom.

The main challenge is the lack of dialogue between the UOC and the OCU. Instead of communication, there is public confrontation, mutual accusations, and growing toxicity. This destroys the image of both sides and forms a negative perception of Ukrainian Orthodoxy as a whole.

According to Vasilevich, the way out is through joint educational, cultural, and theological initiatives that unite, rather than divide. Self-criticism and the ability to show solidarity with a "competitor" are signs of maturity, which are sorely lacking today.

#ukraine #uoc #ocu Source channel: test_source Source channel: test_source

Archpriest of the UOC Sergey Prokopchuk: the only way out for the UOC is to restore communication with Constantinople

On the eve of the possible Bishops' Council of the UOC, which may take place on May 27, Archpriest Sergey Prokopchuk stated that there can be no talk of autocephaly for the UOC. The only way is to restore the unity of Ukrainian Orthodoxy and Eucharistic communion with Constantinople.

The priest proposed specific steps that, in his opinion, could lead to reconciliation and a way out of the crisis:

‚ñ™Ô∏èRestoration of Eucharistic communion with the Patriarchate of Constantinople and other Local Churches. ‚ñ™Ô∏èRecognition of the UOC as part of the Kyiv Metropolis in the Ecumenical Patriarchate - without additional decisions, as this is already recorded in the documents of 2018. ‚ñ™Ô∏èWithdrawal by the state of all legal claims against the UOC and the cessation of inter-church conflicts. ‚ñ™Ô∏èAppointment by the Ecumenical Patriarch of a transitional period for the rapprochement of jurisdictions and dialogue on complex issues.

"This is what world Orthodoxy expects from us. This is what society wants. This is what Moscow fears," the archpriest emphasized, adding: "The love of God and the fear of punishment must heal the wounds inflicted by the division."

#ukraine #uoc #pcu Source channel: test_source

-1002328631739.html:
"You are not alone": a sermon about the awakening we fear

What happens to a person when they finally open their eyes? In the Sunday sermon of the anti-war priest Alexander Kukhta, awakening is not so much a relief as a challenge. As in the Gospel story of the healing of the blind man, today too one can be interrogated, lose loved ones, a job, a homeland, freedom for one's awakening.

Father Alexander is a priest from Belarus who left the country due to repression. Today he serves in exile, continues to preach and support those who, like him, have chosen the path of truth.

#orthodox #sermon Source channel: Christians Against War!
